thread.title: Power gets Toronto past Royals
thread.title_full: Power gets Toronto past Royals - Times Union

author: timesunion.com
title: Power gets Toronto past Royals
text:
Photo: Chris Young Image 1 of / 1 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 1 Toronto Blue Jays' Ryan Goins hits a home run off Kansas City Royals' pitcher Kris Medlen as catcher Salvador Perez looks on during the fifth inning in Game 3 of baseball's American League Championship Series on Monday, Oct. 19, 2015, in Toronto. (Chris Young/The Canadian Press via AP) MANDATORY CREDIT ORG XMIT: CHY106 Toronto Blue Jays' Ryan Goins hits a home run off Kansas City Royals' pitcher Kris Medlen as catcher Salvador Perez looks on during the fifth inning in Game 3 of baseball's American League Championship ... more Photo: Chris Young Power gets Toronto past Royals 1 / 1 Back to Gallery Toronto
Troy Tulowitzki , Josh Donaldson and the Toronto Blue Jays were eager to return home after dropping the first two games of the AL Championship Series in Kansas City .
They showed everyone why.
Tulowitzki and Donaldson connected in a six-run third inning as Toronto roughed up Johnny Cueto and the Royals for an 11-8 victory that cut Kansas City's series lead to 2-1.
"That's really what we're all about," manager John Gibbons said. "We desperately needed that breakout."
Veteran knuckleballer R.A. Dickey will try to get the Blue Jays even in the best-of-seven series Tuesday afternoon. He faces Kansas City's 6-foot-10 right-hander Chris Young in Game 4.
More Information
ALCS
Blue Jays vs. Royals
All games televised by FS1
Game 1: Kansas City, 5-0
Game 2: Kansas City, 6-3
Game 3: Toronto, 11-8
Tuesday: Kansas City (Young 11-6) at Toronto (Dickey 11-11), 4:07 p.m.
Wednesday: at Toronto, 4:07 p.m.
x-Friday: at Kansas City, 8:07 p.m.
x-Saturday: at Kansas City, 8:07 p.m.
x-if necessary
Ryan Goins also homered and had a two-run single.
The resilient Royals scored four runs in the ninth before Roberto Osuna closed it out.
Tulowitzki was given a rare playoff ejection for arguing balls and strikes before the top of the eighth.
Despite being outhit 15-11, the Blue Jays, in the first ALCS game in Toronto since 1993, scored their most runs ever at home in the postseason â€” after scoring just three in two games in Kansas City.
Kansas City scored four times off starter Marcus Stroman and added four in the ninth, capped by Kendrys Morales' two-run homer off Osuna.
